title: Marathi language
summary: Marathi (English:  /məˈrɑːti/;[3] मराठी, Marāṭhī, Marathi: [məˈɾaːʈʰiː] (listen)) is an Indo-Aryan language spoken predominantly by Marathi people in the Indian state of Maharashtra. It is the only official language of Maharashtra, and a co-official language in the Goa state and the Damaon territory in western India. It is one of the 22 scheduled languages of India, with 83 million speakers as of 2011, Marathi ranks 10th in the list of languages with most native speakers in the world. Marathi has the third largest number of native speakers in India, after Hindi-Urdu and Bengali.[4] The language has some of the oldest literature of all modern Indian languages, dating from around 600 AD.[5] The major dialects of Marathi are Standard Marathi and the Varhadi dialect.[6] Ahirani of the Khandesh subregion, Koli, Aagri& Malvani Konkanis have been heavily influenced by Marathi varieties.
